legislation.statute: Michigan's RPS was enacted by Public Act 295 in October 2008. In total, this act will require that electric providers in Michigan produce 10% of their energy from renewable sources by 2015. The first compliance period began in 2012. The annual requirements are determined for each utility based on statutorily defined increments between 2007 baseline and the 2015 goal. In addition to these percentage requirements (which can be fulfilled through REC purchases), large utilities have additional capacity requirements.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar Thermal Electric, Photovoltaics, Landfill Gas, Wind, Biomass, Hydroelectric, Geothermal Electric, Municipal Solid Waste, CHP/Cogeneration, Coal-Fired w/CCS, Gasification, Anaerobic Digestion, Tidal Energy, Wave Energy

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: If out of state, RECs must be generated with the 'retail electric customer service territory of any provider that is not an alternative electric supplier' (PA 295 §29(1))

rps_tech_details.name: Sectors
rps_tech_details.description: Municipal Utility, Investor-Owned Utility, Rural Electric Cooperative, Retail Supplier

rps_tech_details.name: Non-compliance Penalty
rps_tech_details.description: Utilities who fail to comply with annual targets may not be allowed to recover the cost of any RECs purchased from ratepayer. The attorney general may file suit against uncooperative utilities. (§ 53)

legislation.carveouts: Michigan's RPS does not have any technology requirements.
legislation.cost_cap_details: Monthly rate impact is capped at $3.00 for residential customers, $16.58 for secondary commercial customers and $187.50 for primary commercial/industrial customers.

snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart allows you to compare your state's policy pathway to its neighbors. Maryland's pathway is red. Click on another state to learn more about their RPS.
snapshot.summary: Michigan's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Michigan.
